The most delightful and health-giving resorts for Anglo-Egyptian Officials'are the Alpine districts of Austria, which ean be reached in a few hours from Trieste. Excellent Hotels (to suit every pocket) abound situated in high latitudee of great recuperative power specially recommended by doctors for those who have spent a con- siderable time in a hot climate. Various high Anglo-Egyptian Officials have already engaged villas, rooms at hotels, etc., for the ensuing vacation season. Shootings and Fishings (at very low prices) can be arranged through the Bureau, also Castles and Villas can be 1st or sold. THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Bgypt (including delivery in , Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s addrees) P.T. 231J per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other oountries in the Postal Union P.T. 278 (£2.16s.) per annum. 8ix months P.T. 186} (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions oommei oe from the 1st or 16th of any month.
ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Mi uimam charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three linee, P.T. 20. Bvery additional line P.T. 10. Notioee iu news column P.T. 20 por line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements. SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS xre due in advance. P.0. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria London Offioes : 36, New Broad-streot B.O. The Egyptian Gazette Aa Xaglbk Bally Yawipa^r, KaUblUkrd In ISM. Editor & Manager: R. Snellino. Prloei One Piastre Tariff. THURSDAY, MAY 18 1905 Mr. BALFOUR'S SPEECH. The home papers to hand miming contain full report! of Mr. Balfour’s greit speech in the House of Commous this day week. The Prime Minister's speeoh was a double triumph—for the speaker himself, and for principles with which the party he repre- sents has ever been specially identifiel. It was a personal triumph, inaamuoh as it showed Mr. Balfou'r at his best, rising above the littleness of the daily strife of parties—wherein, for all his skill in debate, the Premier does not exoel because he does not care for the gamo—and sunning himself ia the largo liberty of a theme of permanent patriotic interest of supremo importance. Mr. Balfour is at home on the heights, and thithor, last Thursday, he was able not only to lead that party which stands in a special sense for the care of National and Imperial defeuoe, but to do much more. Ho led even those who habitually affeot to regard the integrity of our Islands and of the British Empire as a matter for which we, like the lilies of the field, need toil not neither spin, beoause there is a law of nature by which 8amson, in all his strength, was not arrayed in suoh I armour of proof as envelops the United King- dom and the vast collection of dependencies which it has, almost unconsciously and wholly unintentionally, gathered round it
However, Mr. Balfour carried the wholeHouse with him, which, we repeat «u a triumph for him an4 for the party which does like Imperial- ism, rightly understood, njnoh—and muoh more to that Furthermore, his speech, as the ■‘Times’’ says, marks a stago in the history of the question of Imperial defence. Why so I Beoause it induced the House of Commons to •ooopt the principle which underlies the crea- tion of the Imperial Defeuoe Committee. We hare but to look back a very few years to realise that the mere creation of a permanent oonsultative body, instead of the tampon cowritters, dealing with questions, having no continuous existence and keeping no continuous records, which was all we ever had before, constitutes a veritable revolution in our procedure. Time was, and not very long ago, when aU the Departments would have arisen and prophesied concerning it that it was a most un-British institution - as, indeed, we are not sure that it is not—aud that we might very weU have gone on as we did, not merely iD pre-Crimean days, but even for thirty years after the war of 1870, and all that followed it, should have roused us to a sense of the realities of the age we live in. Well, God be thanked for our good amends ! As the result of a tardy national awakening we have got a Navy, and there is some hope that, in the course of time, we may even get an Army as weU. Before we do so, however, it is desirable, not to say necessary, that we should know for what precise object we require the land forces for which we pay at present £53,000,000 per annum without getting value for one money. That object, as Mr. Balfour tells us, must be considered from the stand- points of home, colonial, and Indian defence. : As to the Colonies, their fate must depend on that of the mother country: if once England received that “blow over the heart" against which the late Lord Salisbury warned her, ihe individual power of any Colony to resist an enemy would avail no little. To avert the "blow over the heart”—successful invasion of the British islands—we may, Mr. Balfour holds, depend upon the Navy: we do not need an Army for home defense. In his opinion, which is that of the Committee, "serious invasion of. these islands is not an eventuality which we need seriously consider.” Given a sufficiently powerful Navy, that conclu- sion may be accepted without demur, albeit we should be considerably surprised to learn that military entire on the Continent are prepared henceforward to regard successful invasion of England as outside the sphere of praoticsl politics. Let ns here, by the way, congratulate Mr. Balfour upon the admirable tone of his theoretical reference to France as the moat obvious quarter when the invasion most, owing to geographical conditions, be looked for. That a»nmption—happily, now, parely theoretical—need not, of ooarse,exoluda an intelligent appreciation of the foot that Franoe is not the only Continental Power with a greatNavyand with ports oonveniently situat- ed in rather close proximity to the shore of Eng- land. On that latter snbjeot the silence ot the Premier is, perhaps, not lees significant than words would have been—and oonsiderebly lees liable to misconstruction. Wherefore we must again congratulate. It was, however, with the military requirements of the North-West frontier of India that Mr. Balfour was mainly condemed. He showed, in language of the utmost courtesy, but of unflinchiug firmness, that England oan permit no ’extension of the powerful Russian railway system, which has already reached the Afghan border, into the territories of the Ameer. Afghanistan must remain the "glacis,” as Ljrd Cureon has called it, across whioh no possible enemy can be allowed, in peaoe time, to creep np to the walls of the Indian fortress. We cannot be too thankful to Mr. Balfonr for having laid down that fundamental proposition in absolutely unmistakable terms. To do that was all the more necessary because our inevitable result of the present war in the Par East must be to throw the expansive energy of Russia baok upon the Middle East. It is towards India, aud towards the Per- sian Gulf, that Russian ambition will ne- cessarily look, and it will be for us to see to it that Russia shall not find in either of those directions her line of least resistance That is a theme which might be discussed at any length ; for the preseut we have only to thank the Prime Minister for his luminous and comprehensive exposition of that whole pro- blem ol the defense of the Empire which must be the permanent object of the solicitude of a strong and continuous military policy.
